text: James W. Mason (1841–1875) was an American politician and the first African American postmaster in the United States. ==Early life== James W. Mason was born in 1841 in Chicot County, Arkansas.James W. Mason (1841–1875), The Encyclopedia of Arkansas History & Culture His father, Elisha Worthington, was a Kentucky-born large landowner and the owner of the Sunnyside Plantation in Chicot County. His mother was an African slave owned by his father. As a result, he was a mulatto. He had a sister, Martha. He studied at Oberlin College in Ohio. He also studied in France. ==Career== Mason was appointed as the postmaster of Sunnyside in 1867.Deanna Boyd, Kendra Chen, The History and Experience of African Americans in America’s Postal Service, National Postal Museum As a result, he was the first African-American postmaster in all of the United States. He served as a member of the Arkansas Senate from 1868 to 1869. He was appointed as Consul General to Liberia on March 29, 1870.U.S. Department of State: Office of the Historian However, he failed to fill the position. He served in the Arkansas Senate a second time, from 1871 to 1872. He then served as the Sheriff of Chicot County from 1872 to 1874. In the summer of 1873, he was arrested under the suspicion of inciting a race war in the county. However, the judge, Colonel John A. Williams, dismissed the trial. ==Personal life== He married Rachel, who was also of mixed race. They had a daughter, Fannie. Mason died in 1875. ==References== Category:1841 births Category:1875 deaths Category:People from Chicot County, Arkansas Category:American postmasters Category:Arkansas state senators Category:African-American people in Arkansas politics Category:19th-century American politicians
